Award.AwardTitle: MRI-R2: Acquisition of a Hybrid CPU/GPU and Visualization Cluster for Multidisciplinary Studies in Transport Physics with Uncertainty Quantification

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
0960306
Shaqfeh

"This award is funded under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 (Public Law 111-5)."

This proposal is for the acquisition of a high performance, Hybrid CPU/GPU and Visualization Cluster (HPVC) that is designed to serve the needs of 7 working groups where each is involved in HPC research to solve problems of large global and national impact. The unique aspects of the HPVC cluster lies, in the combination of state-of-the art computer visualization, enhanced performance with large datasets via GPU architecture, and the development of computational uncertainty quantification (UQ). These elements, , will be employed in the solution of interdisciplinary, multiphysics transport problems including (a) engineering Nutrient Transport in Oceanographic Coral Reef Flows (to protect our environment and save the reefs), (b) the Development of Trauma and Nanoparticle Cancer Therapies including understanding hemostasis in the microcirculation (impacting human health), (c) Modeling the Dispersion of Biological Agents in Urban Environments (for Homeland Security), (d) using Quantum Chemistry to Design Catalysts for Fuel Cells (toward sustainable energy development), (e) simulating the Molecular Dynamics of Proteins and the Ribosome (for understanding the basic processes of life), (f) developing a fundamental understanding of Jet Noise Creation (to develop effective noise mitigation strategies for jets, fans, etc.), and finally, (g) to create algorithms for Design Optimization for Sustainable Building Development (as a contribution toward the larger issue of sustainability). The HPVC will play a key role in education, via bringing CPU with GPU enhanced acceleration to the classroom in a spectrum of Stanford courses as well as new workshops on GPU computing. The concept of Uncertainty Quantification as applied to large scale HPC problems will be introduced via a new UQ pipeline as a novel software deliverable within the HPVC research program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Simply put, the hybrid cluster, named "Certainty" has allowed revolutionary impact  the development and application of computational tools and methodologies for the predictive simulation of multi-physics  flows. These methodologies were applied to a wide range of flow configurations including: scramjet engines used for hypersonic flight propulsion, vertical axis wind turbine farms for energy generation, high-lift device configurations used in take-off and landing operations in commercial aviation, supercritical mixing and combustion modeling in rocket propulsion, electro-osmotic instabilities and transition to fully chaotic flows, mixing in jet-in-crossflow configurations for film cooling in turbomachinery and even blood flow simulations at the level of platelet aggregation in the initial stages of clot formulation. Many of these are "first of their kind". Moreover to determine the "uncertainty" in these simulations, we developed unique methodologies for the quantification of margins and uncertainty (QMU) that are directly applicable to multiple other disciplines. These techniques are constituted as general frameworks that can be directly applied to predict the behavior, performance and operability of other engineering devices and the response of natural systems. Finally, the cluster has directly benefited dozens of graduate students and postdoctoral researchers working in the field of computational sciences related to the disciplines of mechanical, aerospace, chemical, and civil engineering, by providing access to a mid-sized state-of-the-art computer cluster within an academic setting. This technological training is fundamental to enable our students and postdoctoral fellows to continue their careers in computational science at those national facilities or elsewhere in academic institutions or industry.
